sectionCopy.name: Clean energy policy
sectionCopy.value:
Argentina published in 2015 the Law 27.191, in which it implements incentives and targets for renewables. The law created the Trust Fund for the Development of Renewable Energies (FODER) and provided tax incentives such as a VAT tax rebate and accelerated depreciation. According to the law, Argentina should have met 8% of its power demand with clean sources in 2018. The country fell short, serving 2.5% of its demand with renewable electricity. The policy established a gradual increase in the target each year, reaching 20% by 2025.
Under Resolution 281/2017, Argentina also established that large power consumers (>300kW) need to comply with targets established by Law 27.191 and may enter into bilateral corporate power purchase agreements. Projects subscribed to the scheme receive priority of dispatch. Following Law 27.191, the country implemented a series of renewable power auctions, RenovAr, to spur the development of clean energy projects. As of November 2018, RenovAr tenders have contracted a total of 4.7GW of renewables projects at large-scale. In May 2019, the country held a mini-tender aimed to small-scale projects and awarded 259MW of renewable projects across the country.

sectionCopy.name: Clean energy investment
sectionCopy.value:
A scarcity of capital, price-distorting subsidies and political risk combined to make Argentina an unappealing destination for clean energy investment in the first half of this decade. That began to change in December 2015 with the arrival of President Mauricio Macri. Since then, Macri's government has sought to cut subsidies and liberalize energy markets to spur conventional and renewable project build underwritten with foreign capital. 
FODER, created under Macri's administration, was backed by the World Bank, which provided guarantees of payments for the renewable tenders. The guarantees boosted confidence among foreign debt providers. Only then did Argentina begin to see financing in the sector, accounting for $3.7 billion since 2016 and peaking in 2018 with $1.9 billion, a record for the industry in that country. Despite the recent progress, however, Argentina's latest re-entry into macroeconomic crisis may push investors away and create difficulties for auction-winning projects that have yet to secure financing.

sectionCopy.name: Power prices and LCOEs
sectionCopy.value: Since Macri took power, electricity prices have spiked, as customer subsidies have been cut. Since 2015, industrial prices grew by 1,054%, while residential and commercial increased by 1,041% and 911% by end-2018, respectively. CAMMESA, the governmental market regulator, regulates tariffs and is also the offtaker for the RenovAr auctions. Auction bids dedicated to large-scale projects have consistently dropped in each round, averaging $59.6/MWh in the first, $54/MWh in the second, and $42.4/MWh in the last round.

sectionCopy.name: Power market
sectionCopy.value:
Argentina's power matrix remains largely reliant on thermal and large hydro assets. Currently, 51% of installed capacity is gas power plants, with hydro representing 28%. The country has a considerable amount of oil & diesel assets at 11% of the mix. Argentina added 1.6GW of thermal capacity in the last year alone. Renewables share increased from 2.5% in 2017 to 4% by 2018 thanks to the commissioning of projects awarded in RenovAr.
The total capacity of wind and solar assets, less than 300MW in 2017, reached nearly 1GW by 2018. For the first time, wind generation achieved the same level as small hydro. Despite the dramatic increase in wind generation, Argentina fell far short of its 8% renewables goal by year-end 2018. By then, only 2.5% of its generation came from small hydro, wind, solar and biomass.

sectionCopy.name: Doing business
sectionCopy.value: Argentina's clean energy investment has been affected by the recent macroeconomic and political crises. At risk is the financing of projects from RenovAr 2, which awarded contracts to 1.8GW of wind and solar assets. Additionally, the Ministry of Energy decreased considerably the amount of capacity tendered in 2018. RenovAr MiniRen 3 focused on small-scale projects and awarded only 259MW of clean energy projects due to transmission limitations. The country planned to launch a public-private partnership in order to expand its power grid but has delayed the plans due to a severe devaluation of the Argentine peso. On the positive side, thanks to Resolution 281/2017, which obligates large consumers to meet renewables targets, the country has seen a significant increase in corporate PPAs to procure clean power.

sectionCopy.name: Barriers
sectionCopy.value: Despite Macri government initiatives to boost clean energy and cut emissions, Argentina has a long road ahead to achieve its targets. Efforts to rebuild international investor confidence are a work in progress, as the country continues to navigate macroeconomic and political crises. The current crisis will likely hurt the ability of projects to obtain financing, especially for the most recent auction, RenovAr Round 2, and RenovAr MiniRen 3. Constrained transmission and distribution networks will inhibit wind and solar build. While Argentina has taken important steps to foster its clean energy industry, important barriers remain.
